questions.text:
A patient presented with the following finding. Which of the following can cause this condition?

1. Elevated vascular hydrostatic pressure
2. Reduced vascular hydrostatic pressure
3. Elevated plasma osmotic pressure
4. Reduced plasma osmotic pressure
questions.solution:
The finding seen in the given image is pitting edema. Edema can be caused by elevated hydrostatic pressure and reduced colloid osmotic pressure.

Under normal circumstances, there is little net movement of fluid out of vessels due to the balance of:

  • Vascular hydrostatic pressure which has the tendency to push water and salts out of capillaries into the interstitial space
  • Plasma osmotic pressure or colloid oncotic pressure which has a tendency to pull water and salts back into vessels.

The pressure dynamics seen inside a capillary is given below.

At arterial end At venous end
  • Capillary hydrostatic pressure = 30-35 mmHg
  • Capillary hydrostatic pressure = 15-20 mmHg
  • Osmotic Pressure = 25 mmHg
  • Osmotic Pressure = 25 mmHg
  • Hydrostatic Pressure > Osmotic Pressure → Fluid moves out of the capillary
  • Hydrostatic Pressure < Osmotic Pressure → Fluid moves into the capillary

Many pathologic disorders are associated with an increase in capillary hydrostatic pressure or a decrease in plasma osmotic pressure, which lead to edema.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about transudate?

choices.text: It is a non-inflammatory edema or effusion
It is a protein-poor and cell-poor fluid
It has a specific gravity of less than 1.012
It is caused by increased vascular permeability

questions.solution:
Transudate results from increased fluid pressures or diminished oncotic forces in the plasma and is not due to increased vascular permeability.

There are 2 types of extravascular fluid - transudate and exudate 

Transudate Exudate
Non-inflammatory edema Inflammatory edema
Ultrafiltrate of plasma Increased vascular permeability caused by inflammatory mediators 
Low protein content (<3g/dl), mainly albumin High (>3g/dl) protein content
No tendency to coagulate Coagulates readily due to high content of fibrinogen
Low specific gravity (<1.012) High specific gravity (>1.018)
Low LDH levels High LDH levels
Low cell count (< 500-1000/ µL)  High cell count
Eg. Edema in congestive cardiac failure Eg. Pus

These differences are depicted in the image below.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions does edema result from decreased colloidal osmotic pressure?
questions.solution:
In nephrotic syndrome, edema occurs due to massive proteinuria that leads to a decrease in plasma colloid osmotic pressure.

The common causes of reduced plasma osmotic pressure are conditions that cause inadequate synthesis or increased loss of albumin (mainly) and other plasma proteins from circulation. These conditions include:

  • Protein-losing glomerulopathies (nephrotic syndrome)
  • Liver cirrhosis (ascites)
  • Malnutrition
  • Protein-losing gastroenteropathy

Edema can also occur due to increased hydrostatic pressure as a result of impaired venous return. This is seen in conditions like:

  • Congestive heart failure
  • Deep venous thrombosis
  • Renal artery stenosis

questions.text: Which of the following is not true?

choices.text: Periorbital edema is seen in severe renal disease
Pitting edema occurs due to edema in subcutaneous tissues
Exudative effusions are typically protein-rich and cloudy
Chylous peritoneal effusion is an example of an exudate

questions.solution:
Chylous peritoneal effusion caused by the lymphatic blockage is an example of a transudate.

Transudative effusions are typically protein-poor, translucent, and straw-colored. However, there may be certain exceptions like chylous peritoneal effusions which may be milky due to the presence of lipids absorbed from the gut.

Exudative effusions are protein-rich and often cloudy due to the presence of WBCs.

Subcutaneous edema has the following features:

  • Dependent edema - dependent areas (towards gravity) have high hydrostatic pressures i.e., in the legs when standing and the sacrum when recumbent
  • Pitting edema - finger pressure over markedly edematous subcutaneous tissue displaces the interstitial fluid and leaves a depression.

Edema resulting from renal dysfunction often appears initially in parts of the body containing loose connective tissue, such as the eyelids. Thus, periorbital edema is a characteristic finding in severe renal disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Arteriolar dilation is seen in hyperemia.

questions.solution:
Hyperemia is seen in inflammation, not congestion.

The differences between hyperemia and congestion are summarised below:

Hyperemia Congestion
Active process due to arteriolar dilation Passive process due to impaired venous outflow
Edema is absent Edema is present
Red color of the tissues Blue-red color of the tissue (due to deoxyhemoglobin) 
Seen in inflammation Seen in right heart failure and portal venous obstruction in cirrhosis

questions.text: An 82-year-old man presents to the ER with fever and tachycardia since last night. On examination, he is drowsy, his BP is 92/54 mmHg and his temperature is 103 °F. His wife tells you he had been diagnosed with a urinary tract infection 5 days ago for which he had been prescribed antibiotics. He is a known case of colon cancer and also has a history of myocardial infarction 6 months ago. What type of shock is he likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of septic shock as a result of gram-negative sepsis originating from a urinary tract infection.

Gram-negative organisms contain lipopolysaccharide in the outer membrane, which triggers the release of cytokines, such as tumor necrosis factor (TNF). These cytokines cause a cascade of events culminating in increased capillary permeability and redistribution of circulatory volume into the interstitium. It is also known as warm shock, due to fever and increased perfusion.

Other types of shock are:

  • Anaphylactic shock - sudden circulatory collapse due to type I hypersensitivity reaction
  • Cardiogenic shock - ventricular failure, often following myocardial infarction; is a form of cold shock
  • Hypovolemic shock - due to blood or fluid loss

questions.text: What is the first step of hemostasis?

choices.text: Binding of platelets to exposed vWF

questions.solution:
The first step of hemostasis is arteriolar vasoconstriction.

The normal process of hemostasis is as follows:

  1. Arteriolar vasoconstriction - After vascular injury, local neurohumoral factors induce transient vasoconstriction.
  2. Primary hemostasis - The various steps involved in this process are:
    • Platelets bind via glycoprotein Ib (GpIb) receptors to von Willebrand factor (vWF) on exposed extracellular matrix (ECM)
    • Activation of platelets which undergo a change in shape and release their granules
    • Released adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and thromboxane A2 (TxA2) induce additional platelet aggregation through platelet GpIIb-IIIa receptor binding to fibrinogen
    • Formation of the primary platelet plug
  3. Secondary hemostasis - Local activation of the coagulation cascade involving tissue factor and platelet phospholipids results in fibrin polymerization, cementing the platelets into a definitive secondary hemostatic plug.
  4. Clot stabilization and resorption - Counter-regulatory mechanisms, mediated by tissue plasminogen activator (tPA, a fibrinolytic product) and thrombomodulin, confine the hemostatic process to the site of injury.

questions.text: Which of the following coagulation factors is bound and activated by tissue factor?
questions.solution:
The tissue factor binds and activates factor VII.

Tissue factor is produced by the subendothelial cells in the vessel wall such as vascular smooth muscle cells and fibroblasts. It is a membrane-bound procoagulant glycoprotein.

Secondary hemostasis involves a sequence of events, which results in the polymerization of fibrin. This is achieved by cross-linking fibrin monomers into insoluble strands that serve to stabilize the loose platelet clot formed in primary hemostasis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not found in α-granules of platelets?
questions.solution:
Serotonin is present in the dense or delta(δ) granules of the platelets, not alpha(α) granules.

Platelets are disc-shaped, anucleate cell fragments that are released from the megakaryocytes in the bone marrow into the bloodstream. The functions of these platelets depend on their glycoprotein receptors, contractile cytoskeleton, and cytoplasmic granules.

There are two types of cytoplasmic granules present in platelets:

  • Alpha granules
  • Dense or delta granules

α-granules contain:

  • Adhesion molecule P-selectin on their membranes
  • Proteins involved in coagulation like -
    • Fibrinogen
    • Coagulation factor V
    • vWF
  • Protein factors involved in wound healing like -
    • Fibronectin
    • Platelet factor 4 (a heparin-binding chemokine)
    • Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)
    • Transforming growth factor β (TGF β)

 δ-granules contain:

  • Adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and adenosine triphosphate (ATP)
  • Ionized calcium
  • Serotonin
  • Epinephrine

questions.text: A patient with prolonged bleeding is found to have vitamin K deficiency. The function of which of the following clotting factors would be unaffected in this condition?
questions.solution:
A deficiency of vitamin K does not alter the function of factor V.

Vitamin K is required as a cofactor for the γ-carboxylation of factors II, VII, IX, and X. Calcium binds to γ-­carboxylated glutamic acid residues that are present in these factors during clotting.

This action of vitamin K is antagonized by drugs such as warfarin, which is widely used as an anticoagulant.

questions.text: The function of which of the following factors is not screened by the partial thromboplastin time assay?
questions.solution:
The partial thromboplastin time (PTT) assay screens the function of the proteins in the intrinsic pathway. As factor VII is only a part of the extrinsic pathway, it cannot be assessed by this test.

The factors assessed by the PTT assay are XII, XI, IX, VIII, X, V, and II and fibrinogen.

In this assay, clotting of plasma is initiated by the addition of negatively charged particles (e.g., ground glass) that activate factor XII (Hageman factor) together with phospholipids and calcium, and the time to fibrin clot formation is recorded.

questions.text: What is the function of thrombomodulin?
questions.solution:
Thrombomodulin is an anticoagulant.

It is produced by all endothelial cells except those in cerebral microcirculation. It binds to thrombin on the endothelial cell surface. When bound in this complex, thrombin loses its ability to activate coagulation factors and platelets, and instead cleaves and activates protein C. Activated protein C/protein S complex is a potent inhibitor of coagulation factors Va and VIIIa. This action results in an anticoagulant effect. 

The effect of recombinant thrombomodulin administration in sepsis-induced coagulopathy and DIC is being studied currently.

Other important anticoagulant substances are:

  • Antithrombin III - It inhibits the activity of thrombin and other factors like XIIa, XIa, Xa, and IXa. It is activated by binding to heparin-like molecules.
  • Proteins C and S - These proteins are vitamin K–dependent proteins that inactivate factors Va and VIIIa.
  • Endothelial prostacyclin (PGI2) and nitric oxide (NO) - These are potent vasodilators and inhibitors of platelet aggregation.
  • Tissue factor pathway inhibitor - This is derived from the endothelium and inhibits tissue factor VIIa and Xa molecules.

questions.text: Leiden mutation is of factor:
questions.solution:
Leiden mutation is a single nucleotide mutation that occurs in factor V. This is named after the city in The Netherlands where it was discovered.

Of the inherited causes of hypercoagulability, point mutations in the factor V gene and prothrombin gene are the most common. 

Related Pearl: Hypercoagulable states

Primary (Genetic Conditions):

  • Mutations in factor V (Most common)
  • Antithrombin III deficiency
  • Protein C or S deficiency
  • Fibrinolysis defects
  • Homocysteinemia
  • Allelic variations in prothrombin levels
  • Mutations in the methyl tetra hydro folate (MTHF) gene

Secondary (Acquired Conditions):

  • Prolonged bed rest or immobilization
  • Homocysteinemia
  • Tissue damage (Surgery, fracture, burns)
  • Cancer
  • Myocardial infarction, Prosthetic cardiac valves
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
  • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of Virchow's triad?
questions.solution:
Hyperviscosity is not part of Virchow’s triad. However, hyperviscosity states as in polycythemia vera may, in turn, cause small vessel stasis that may cause thrombosis.

Virchow's triad in thrombosis:

  1. Injury to endothelial cells can alter local blood flow and affect coagulability.
  2. Abnormal blood flow (stasis or turbulence), in turn, can cause endothelial injury.
  3. Hypercoagulability of blood

These factors may promote thrombosis independently or in combination.

questions.text: In which of the following structures are lines of Zahn seen?
questions.solution:
Thrombi often have grossly and microscopically apparent laminations called lines of Zahn. These are formed by pale platelet and fibrin deposits alternating with darker red cell-rich layers.

They signify that a thrombus has formed in flowing blood. Their presence can therefore distinguish antemortem clots from the nonlaminated postmortem clots.

The below histopathological image of a thrombus shows these alternating bands called lines of Zahn.

questions.text: Which of the following do chicken fat clots refer to?
questions.solution:
Chicken fat clots refer to post-mortem clots i.e., clots that are formed after death.

Postmortem clots are gelatinous and have a dark red (currant jelly) dependent portion where red cells have settled by gravity and a yellow (chicken fat) upper portion due to coagulation of plasma.

Antemortem clots can be differentiated from postmortem clots by:

  • Presence of lines of Zahn
  • Attachment to the underlying vessel wall

questions.text: Saddle embolus is seen in which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
An embolus in the bifurcation of the main pulmonary artery is referred to as a saddle embolus.

Pulmonary emboli (PE) originate from deep venous thromboses and are the most common form of thromboembolic disease. In more than 95% of cases, PE originates from leg deep vein thrombi (DVTs).

Fragmented thrombi from DVTs are carried through progressively larger veins and the right side of the heart, before slamming into the pulmonary arterial vasculature. Depending on the size of the embolus, it can have 3 fates:

  • It can occlude the main pulmonary artery
  • It can straddle the pulmonary artery bifurcation (saddle embolus)
  • It can pass out into the smaller, branching arteries

The CT image given below shows a saddle embolus lodged in the main pulmonary artery extending into both its limbs as indicated by the red arrows.

questions.text: Following autopsy, an H&E stained specimen of the lung was obtained which is given below. What could be the likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the presence of laminated swirls of squamous cells in the pulmonary arteriole which is characteristically seen in amniotic fluid embolism(AFE).

AFE is a life-threatening obstetric emergency characterized by sudden cardiorespiratory collapse and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The underlying cause is the infusion of amniotic fluid or fetal tissue into the maternal circulation via a tear in the placental membranes or rupture of uterine veins.

Findings at autopsy include:

  • Presence in the maternal pulmonary micro-vasculature of-
    • Squamous cells shed from fetal skin
    • Lanugo hair
    • Fat from vernix caseosa
    • Mucin derived from the fetal respiratory or gastrointestinal tract 
  • Marked pulmonary edema
  • Diffuse alveolar damage
  • Presence of fibrin thrombi in many vascular beds due to DIC

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in patients with DIC?
questions.solution:
Increased prothrombin time (PT) is a feature of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acute, subacute, or chronic thrombohemorrhagic disorder occurring as a secondary complication in a variety of diseases.

It is characterized by the activation of the coagulation sequence, which leads to the formation of microthrombi throughout the microcirculation of the body. As a consequence of the thrombotic diathesis, there is a consumption of platelets, fibrin, and coagulation factors and, secondarily, activation of fibrinolytic mechanisms.

Laboratory investigations in DIC reveal the following:

  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Prolonged prothrombin time (PT)/thrombin time (TT)
  • Decreased fibrinogen level 
  • Elevated levels of fibrin-split products (D-dimers)

questions.text: Red infarcts do not occur in which of the following organs?
questions.solution:
White infarcts occur in the spleen, not red infarcts.

Red infarcts occur in the following conditions:

  • Venous occlusions (e.g., testicular torsion)
  • Loose, spongy tissues (e.g., lung), where blood can collect in the infarcted zone
  • Tissues with dual circulations (e.g., lung and small intestine), which allows blood to flow from an unobstructed parallel supply into a necrotic zone
  • Tissues previously congested by sluggish venous outflow
  • When flow is re-established at a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis (e.g., following angioplasty of an arterial obstruction)

 The below image shows a hemorrhagic, roughly wedge-shaped pulmonary red infarct.

White infarcts occur with arterial occlusions in solid organs with end-arterial circulation (e.g., heart, spleen, and kidney), and where tissue density limits the seepage of blood from adjoining capillary beds into the necrotic area.

The below image shows a sharply demarcated white infarct in the spleen.

Septic infarctions occur when infected cardiac valve vegetations embolize or when microbes seed necrotic tissue. In these cases, the infarct is converted into an abscess, with a correspondingly greater inflammatory response.

questions.text: A bridge construction worker presents with generalized bone pain. He is found to have ischemic necrosis of bilateral femoral heads, left tibia, and right humerus. Caisson disease is suspected. What is this condition related to?
questions.solution:
Caisson disease is a chronic form of decompression sickness which occurs when individuals experience a sudden decrease in atmospheric pressure.

It is named after the pressurized vessels that are used in bridge construction as workers in these vessels are known to suffer from both acute and chronic forms of decompression sickness.

When air is breathed at high pressure, increased amounts of gas, particularly nitrogen, are dissolved in the blood and tissues. If there is a sudden fall in pressure, the nitrogen comes out of the solution in the tissues and the blood and forms gas emboli. In Caisson disease, the persistence of gas emboli in the skeletal system leads to the development of multiple foci of ischemic necrosis. The more common sites are the femoral heads, tibia, and humeri.

questions.text: Chest X-ray of a 60-year-old woman with dyspnoea at rest revealed right-sided pleural effusion. A pleural fluid analysis was done. Which of the following findings would rule out a transudative cause?
questions.solution:
High plasma protein content in the pleural fluid would rule out a transudative cause. In a transudative effusion, the fluid has low protein content, little or no cellular material, and low specific gravity.

It is essentially an ultrafiltrate of the blood plasma. It is produced as a result of osmotic or hydrostatic imbalance across the vessel wall. There is no increase in vascular permeability.

The table below gives the differences between transudative and exudative effusion.

Features Transudate Exudate
Process Passive (increased pressure) Active (inflammation)
Vascular permeability Normal Increased
Plasma protein leak Absent Present
Protein content of fluid

Low S.G<1.012

Low protein

High S.G>1.020

High protein
Fibrin Absent Present
Inflammatory cells Absent Present

 

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure (most common)
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Myxedema 
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Urinothorax
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Infections: Tuberculosis, pneumonia, intraabdominal abscess (like- liver abscess)
  • Malignancy: Pleural mesothelioma, metastasis, lymphoma
  • Connective tissue diseases: SLE, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Drugs: Amiodarone, bromocriptine, dantrolene, dasatinib, methysergide, nitrofurantoin
  • Others:
    • Pancreatitis
    • Asbestosis
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Hemothorax
    • Chylothorax
    • Meigs' syndrome 
    • Dressler syndrome (post-myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery)
    • Yellow nail syndrome
